SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/docs/man/rabbitmqctl.8.md#2025-04-09_snippet_23 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmqctl clear_permissions -p my-vhost janeway ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Ubuntu 22.04 RabbitMQ Installation Script DESCRIPTION: Complete installation script for RabbitMQ on Ubuntu 22.04 (Jammy). Configures package repositories, installs signing keys, sets up Erlang dependencies, and installs RabbitMQ server. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/install-debian.md#2025-04-09_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` #!/bin/sh sudo apt-get install curl gnupg apt-transport-https -y ## Team RabbitMQ's main signing key curl -1sLf "https://keys.openpgp.org/vks/v1/by-fingerprint/0A9AF2115F4687BD29803A206B73A36E6026DFCA" | sudo gpg --dearmor | sudo tee /usr/share/keyrings/com.rabbitmq.team.gpg > /dev/null ## Community mirror of Cloudsmith: modern Erlang repository curl -1sLf https://github.com/rabbitmq/signing-keys/releases/download/3.0/cloudsmith.rabbitmq-erlang.E495BB49CC4BBE5B.key | sudo gpg --dearmor | sudo tee /usr/share/keyrings/rabbitmq.E495BB49CC4BBE5B.gpg > /dev/null ## Community mirror of Cloudsmith: RabbitMQ repository curl -1sLf https://github.com/rabbitmq/signing-keys/releases/download/3.0/cloudsmith.rabbitmq-server.9F4587F226208342.key | sudo gpg --dearmor | sudo tee /usr/share/keyrings/rabbitmq.9F4587F226208342.gpg > /dev/null ## Add apt repositories maintained by Team RabbitMQ sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/rabbitmq.list < "Hello World!" words -> Enum.join(words, " ") end AMQP.Exchange.declare(channel, "logs", :fanout) AMQP.Basic.publish(channel, "logs", "", message) IO.puts " [x] Sent '#{message}'" AMQP.Connection.close(connection) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring TLS-Only Listeners DESCRIPTION: Deactivates non-TLS listeners and configures TLS settings for secure connections only. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/networking.md#2025-04-09_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: ini CODE: ``` # deactivates non-TLS listeners, only TLS-enabled (activated) clients will be able to connect listeners.tcp = none listeners.ssl.default = 5671 ssl_options.cacertfile = /path/to/ca_certificate.pem ssl_options.certfile = /path/to/server_certificate.pem ssl_options.keyfile = /path/to/server_key.pem ssl_options.verify = verify_peer ssl_options.fail_if_no_peer_cert = false ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Declaring a DirectExchange Bean in Spring AMQP DESCRIPTION: Definition of a DirectExchange bean in Spring configuration. This creates a direct exchange named 'tut.direct' that will route messages based on their routing keys. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/tutorials/tutorial-four-spring-amqp.md#2025-04-09_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: java CODE: ``` @Bean public DirectExchange direct() { return new DirectExchange("tut.direct"); } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Stopping RabbitMQ Node DESCRIPTION: Command to stop the Erlang node running RabbitMQ. Can optionally wait for a specific process to terminate if a PID file is specified. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/docs/man/rabbitmqctl.8.md#2025-04-09_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmqctl stop ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Managing Quorum Queue Members via CLI DESCRIPTION: Command line operations for managing quorum queue replicas, including adding/removing members and growing/shrinking queue membership across nodes. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/quorum-queues/index.md#2025-04-09_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmq-queues add_member [-p ] ``` LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmq-queues delete_member [-p ] ``` LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmq-queues grow [--vhost-pattern ] [--queue-pattern ] ``` LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmq-queues shrink [--errors-only] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting User Permissions in RabbitMQ (Bash) DESCRIPTION: This command sets permissions for a user on a specific virtual host. It requires the virtual host name, username, and regular expressions for configure, write, and read permissions. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/man/rabbitmqctl.8.md#2025-04-09_snippet_30 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmqctl set_permissions -p my-vhost janeway "^janeway-.*" ".*" ".*" ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting Shared Prefetch Limits for Multiple Consumers in Java DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to set both per-consumer and per-channel prefetch limits, resulting in a shared limit between two consumers. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/docs/consumer-prefetch.md#2025-04-09_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: java CODE: ``` Channel channel = ...; Consumer consumer1 = ...; Consumer consumer2 = ...; channel.basicQos(10, false); // Per consumer limit channel.basicQos(15, true); // Per channel limit channel.basicConsume("my-queue1", false, consumer1); channel.basicConsume("my-queue2", false, consumer2); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Adding RabbitMQ Client Dependencies DESCRIPTION: Commands to add the RabbitMQ.Client NuGet package to both projects. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/tutorials/tutorial-one-dotnet.md#2025-04-09_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: powershell CODE: ``` cd Send dotnet add package RabbitMQ.Client cd ../Receive dotnet add package RabbitMQ.Client ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting File Descriptor Limits on Older Linux Distributions DESCRIPTION: Command to set soft file descriptor limits on older Linux distributions without systemd. This can be added to /etc/default/rabbitmq-server or rabbitmq-env.conf. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/docs/install-rpm.md#2025-04-09_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` ulimit -S -n 64000 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Declaring a Durable Queue in PHP RabbitMQ DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to declare a durable queue in RabbitMQ using PHP. The third parameter is set to true to ensure the queue survives server restarts. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/tutorials/tutorial-two-php.md#2025-04-09_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: PHP CODE: ``` $channel->queue_declare('task_queue', false, true, false, false); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Starting RabbitMQ with OAuth Configuration DESCRIPTION: Commands to start RabbitMQ with OAuth provider settings using environment variables and make command. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/oauth2-examples-idp-initiated.md#2025-04-09_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` export MODE=portal OAUTH_PROVIDER=uaa make start-rabbitmq ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing RabbitMQ Cluster Operator with Helm DESCRIPTION: Commands to install the RabbitMQ Cluster Operator using the Bitnami Helm chart, which deploys the operator to the Kubernetes cluster with default configuration. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/kubernetes/operator/install-operator.md#2025-04-09_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` helm repo add bitnami https://charts.bitnami.com/bitnami helm install my-release bitnami/rabbitmq-cluster-operator ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Shutting Down RabbitMQ Node DESCRIPTION: Command to shut down both RabbitMQ and its runtime. Blocks until the runtime process exits and returns non-zero if shutdown fails. Can only be used for nodes on the same host. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/docs/man/rabbitmqctl.8.md#2025-04-09_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmqctl shutdown ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Running RabbitMQ Workers and Task Publishers in Shell DESCRIPTION: Terminal commands demonstrating how to run the worker and task publisher applications. These commands show how to start multiple workers and publish various messages with different processing times. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/tutorials/tutorial-two-go.md#2025-04-09_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` # shell 1 go run worker.go ``` LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` # shell 2 go run worker.go ``` LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` # shell 3 go run new_task.go First message. go run new_task.go Second message.. go run new_task.go Third message... go run new_task.go Fourth message.... go run new_task.go Fifth message..... ``` LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` # shell 1 go run worker.go # => [*] Waiting for messages. To exit press CTRL+C # => [x] Received 'First message.' # => [x] Received 'Third message...' # => [x] Received 'Fifth message.....' ``` LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` # shell 2 go run worker.go # => [*] Waiting for messages. To exit press CTRL+C # => [x] Received 'Second message..' ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Fetching Messages on Demand in AMQP 0-9-1 DESCRIPTION: Messages can be fetched on demand using the basic.get method, which also allows specifying the acknowledgement mode for the fetched message. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/docs/confirms.md#2025-04-09_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: AMQP CODE: ``` basic.get ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Binding Exchanges Using RabbitMQ Java Client DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to bind a destination exchange to a source exchange with a routing key using the RabbitMQ Java client. The exchangeBind method creates a unidirectional binding where messages will flow from the source exchange to the destination exchange. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/e2e.md#2025-04-09_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: java CODE: ``` Channel ch = conn.createChannel(); ch.exchangeBind("destination", "source", "routingKey"); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Shutting Down RabbitMQ Node DESCRIPTION: Command to shut down both RabbitMQ and its runtime. Blocks until the runtime process exits and returns non-zero if shutdown fails. Can only be used for nodes on the same host. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/docs/man/rabbitmqctl.8.md#2025-04-09_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmqctl shutdown ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Batch Message Acknowledgement in Java DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to acknowledge multiple messages at once using RabbitMQ Java client. Uses Channel#basicAck with multiple flag set to true. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/confirms.md#2025-04-09_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: java CODE: ``` boolean autoAck = false; channel.basicConsume(queueName, autoAck, "a-consumer-tag", new DefaultConsumer(channel) { @Override public void handleDelivery(String consumerTag, Envelope envelope, AMQP.BasicProperties properties, byte[] body) throws IOException { long deliveryTag = envelope.getDeliveryTag(); // positively acknowledge all deliveries up to // this delivery tag channel.basicAck(deliveryTag, true); } }); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Channel from a Connection DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to create a channel from an established connection. Channels are used for performing most operations in AMQP. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/client-libraries/java-api-guide.md#2025-04-09_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: Java CODE: ``` Channel channel = conn.createChannel(); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Cancelling a Consumer in RabbitMQ Java Client DESCRIPTION: Shows how to explicitly cancel a consumer using the basicCancel method with a consumer tag. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/client-libraries/java-api-guide.md#2025-04-09_snippet_22 LANGUAGE: Java CODE: ``` channel.basicCancel(consumerTag); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Complete Log Receiver Implementation in Elixir DESCRIPTION: A complete implementation of a log message consumer that connects to RabbitMQ, declares a fanout exchange, creates an exclusive queue, binds it to the exchange, and consumes messages. It continuously listens for and prints received messages. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/tutorials/tutorial-three-elixir.md#2025-04-09_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: elixir CODE: ``` defmodule ReceiveLogs do def wait_for_messages(channel) do receive do {:basic_deliver, payload, _meta} -> IO.puts " [x] Received #{payload}" wait_for_messages(channel) end end end {:ok, connection} = AMQP.Connection.open {:ok, channel} = AMQP.Channel.open(connection) AMQP.Exchange.declare(channel, "logs", :fanout) {:ok, %{queue: queue_name}} = AMQP.Queue.declare(channel, "", exclusive: true) AMQP.Queue.bind(channel, queue_name, "logs") AMQP.Basic.consume(channel, queue_name, nil, no_ack: true) IO.puts " [*] Waiting for messages. To exit press CTRL+C, CTRL+C" ReceiveLogs.wait_for_messages(channel) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring Federation Upstream in PowerShell DESCRIPTION: PowerShell command to set up a federation upstream named 'origin' pointing to a remote RabbitMQ host using the rabbitmqctl CLI tool. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/federated-queues/index.md#2025-04-09_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: powershell CODE: ``` rabbitmqctl.bat set_parameter federation-upstream origin '"{""uri"":""amqp://remote-host.local:5672""}"' ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Batch Message Rejection in .NET DESCRIPTION: Shows how to reject multiple messages at once using RabbitMQ .NET client. Uses IModel#BasicNack with multiple and requeue parameters set to true. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/confirms.md#2025-04-09_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: csharp CODE: ``` var consumer = new EventingBasicConsumer(channel); consumer.Received += (ch, ea) => { var body = ea.Body.ToArray(); // requeue all unacknowledged deliveries up to // this delivery tag channel.BasicNack(ea.DeliveryTag, true, true); }; String consumerTag = channel.BasicConsume(queueName, false, consumer); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Enabling Federation Plugins with rabbitmq-plugins (Bash) DESCRIPTION: Commands to enable the federation plugin and its management UI extension using the rabbitmq-plugins CLI tool. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/docs/federation.md#2025-04-09_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmq-plugins enable rabbitmq_federation ``` LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmq-plugins enable rabbitmq_federation_management ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting Erlang Cookie via Environment Variable in Bash DESCRIPTION: Sets the RABBITMQ_SERVER_ADDITIONAL_ERL_ARGS environment variable to override the Erlang cookie value used by a RabbitMQ node. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/clustering.md#2025-04-09_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` RABBITMQ_SERVER_ADDITIONAL_ERL_ARGS="-setcookie cookie-value" ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Implementing Server-Side Offset Tracking in RabbitMQ Streams with Go DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates how to track consumer progress in a RabbitMQ Stream using server-side offset tracking. It retrieves the last stored offset before creating a consumer, sets up a named consumer with manual commit mode, stores offsets every 10 messages, and handles consumer resumption after restart. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/tutorials/tutorial-two-go-stream.md#2025-04-09_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: go CODE: ``` var firstOffset int64 = -1 var messageCount int64 = -1 // number of received messages var lastOffset atomic.Int64 ch := make(chan bool) messagesHandler := func(consumerContext stream.ConsumerContext, message *amqp.Message) { if atomic.CompareAndSwapInt64(&firstOffset, -1, consumerContext.Consumer.GetOffset()) { fmt.Println("First message received.") } if atomic.AddInt64(&messageCount, 1)%10 == 0 { consumerContext.Consumer.StoreOffset() // store offset every 10 messages } if string(message.GetData()) == "marker" { lastOffset.Store(consumerContext.Consumer.GetOffset()) consumerContext.Consumer.StoreOffset() // store the offset on consumer closing consumerContext.Consumer.Close() ch <- true } } var offsetSpecification stream.OffsetSpecification consumerName := "offset-tracking-tutorial" // name of the consumer storedOffset, err := env.QueryOffset(consumerName, streamName) // get last stored offset if errors.Is(err, stream.OffsetNotFoundError) { // start consuming at the beginning of the stream if no stored offset offsetSpecification = stream.OffsetSpecification{}.First() } else { // start just after the last stored offset offsetSpecification = stream.OffsetSpecification{}.Offset(storedOffset + 1) } _, err = env.NewConsumer(streamName, messagesHandler, stream.NewConsumerOptions(). SetManualCommit(). // activate manual offset tracking SetConsumerName(consumerName). // the consumer must a have name SetOffset(offsetSpecification)) fmt.Println("Started consuming...") _ = <-ch fmt.Printf("Done consuming, first offset %d, last offset %d.\n", firstOffset, lastOffset.Load()) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Environment Variable Interpolation in RabbitMQ Configuration DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to use environment variable interpolation in the rabbitmq.conf file. It shows examples of setting default user credentials and cluster name using environment variables. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/configure.md#2025-04-09_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: ini CODE: ``` # environment variable interpolation default_user = $(SEED_USERNAME) default_pass = $(SEED_USER_PASSWORD) cluster_name = deployment-$(DEPLOYMENT_ID) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring TLS for RabbitMQ Prometheus Endpoint DESCRIPTION: Configuration example for securing the Prometheus metrics endpoint with TLS. This setup specifies SSL port, certificate files, and optional encryption password. The commented line shows how to disable the non-TLS port. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/docs/prometheus/index.md#2025-04-09_snippet_21 LANGUAGE: ini CODE: ``` prometheus.ssl.port = 15691 prometheus.ssl.cacertfile = /full/path/to/ca_certificate.pem prometheus.ssl.certfile = /full/path/to/server_certificate.pem prometheus.ssl.keyfile = /full/path/to/server_key.pem prometheus.ssl.password = password-if-keyfile-is-encrypted ## To enforce TLS (disable the non-TLS port): # prometheus.tcp.listener = none ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Publishing a Message with Severity in Objective-C DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to publish a message to a direct exchange with a severity routing key using the RabbitMQ Objective-C client. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/tutorials/tutorial-four-objectivec.md#2025-04-09_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: objectivec CODE: ``` RMQExchange *x = [ch direct:@"logs"]; [x publish:[msg dataUsingEncoding:NSUTF8StringEncoding] routingKey:severity]; ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Accessing RabbitMQ Prometheus Metrics Endpoint DESCRIPTION: Command to access the metrics endpoint exposed by the Prometheus plugin on port 15692, which serves metrics in Prometheus-compatible format. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/monitoring/index.md#2025-04-09_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` curl {hostname}:15692/metrics ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Channel and Queue for Sending Messages in Ruby DESCRIPTION: Creates a channel and declares a queue for sending messages. This snippet is part of the producer (sender) script. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/tutorials/tutorial-one-ruby.md#2025-04-09_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: ruby CODE: ``` channel = connection.create_channel queue = channel.queue('hello') channel.default_exchange.publish('Hello World!', routing_key: queue.name) puts " [x] Sent 'Hello World!'" connection.close ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring TLSv1.3 in RabbitMQ (INI) DESCRIPTION: Configuration snippet for enabling TLSv1.3 in RabbitMQ. Specifies the SSL listener, certificate files, TLS version, and cipher suites compatible with TLSv1.3. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/ssl/index.md#2025-04-09_snippet_29 LANGUAGE: ini CODE: ``` listeners.ssl.1 = 5671 ssl_options.cacertfile = /path/to/ca_certificate.pem ssl_options.certfile = /path/to/server_certificate.pem ssl_options.keyfile = /path/to/server_key.pem ssl_options.versions.1 = tlsv1.3 # Limits enable cipher suites to only those used by TLSv1.3. # There are no cipher suites supported by both TLSv1.3 and TLSv1.2. ssl_options.ciphers.1 = TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384 ssl_options.ciphers.2 = TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256 ssl_options.ciphers.3 = TLS_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256 ssl_options.ciphers.4 = TLS_AES_128_CCM_SHA256 ssl_options.ciphers.5 = TLS_AES_128_CCM_8_SHA256 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring Stream Protocol Heartbeat Timeout DESCRIPTION: Configuration to adjust the heartbeat timeout for stream protocol connections. The example shows how to reduce it from the default 60 seconds to 20 seconds. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/stream.md#2025-04-09_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: ini CODE: ``` # use a lower heartbeat timeout value stream.heartbeat = 20 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring Relaxed Property Equivalence Checks for Quorum Queues in RabbitMQ DESCRIPTION: This configuration option allows ignoring the 'x-queue-type' header during queue redeclaration, which can simplify upgrades for applications that explicitly set this property to 'classic' for historical reasons. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/quorum-queues/index.md#2025-04-09_snippet_19 LANGUAGE: ini CODE: ``` quorum_queue.property_equivalence.relaxed_checks_on_redeclaration = true ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Message Requeuing in .NET DESCRIPTION: Shows how to requeue messages using RabbitMQ .NET client. Uses IModel#BasicReject with requeue parameter set to true. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/confirms.md#2025-04-09_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: csharp CODE: ``` var consumer = new EventingBasicConsumer(channel); consumer.Received += (ch, ea) => { var body = ea.Body.ToArray(); // requeue the delivery channel.BasicReject(ea.DeliveryTag, true); }; String consumerTag = channel.BasicConsume(queueName, false, consumer); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring Micrometer with JMX for RabbitMQ Java Client Metrics DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to set up Micrometer metrics with JMX reporting for the RabbitMQ Java client. It shows the creation of a JmxMeterRegistry, passing it to the MicrometerMetricsCollector, and setting the collector on the ConnectionFactory. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/client-libraries/java-api-guide.md#2025-04-09_snippet_41 LANGUAGE: java CODE: ``` JmxMeterRegistry registry = new JmxMeterRegistry(); MicrometerMetricsCollector metrics = new MicrometerMetricsCollector(registry); ConnectionFactory connectionFactory = new ConnectionFactory(); connectionFactory.setMetricsCollector(metrics); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Declaring a Durable Queue in RabbitMQ DESCRIPTION: Code to declare a queue that will survive RabbitMQ restarts by setting the durable flag to true. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/tutorials/tutorial-two-go.md#2025-04-09_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: go CODE: ``` q, err := ch.QueueDeclare( "hello", // name true, // durable false, // delete when unused false, // exclusive false, // no-wait nil, // arguments ) failOnError(err, "Failed to declare a queue") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Receiver Output for First Run in Shell DESCRIPTION: Shell output showing the first run of the offset-tracking consumer. It starts from the beginning of the stream (offset 0) and processes messages until it finds the marker at offset 99. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/tutorials/tutorial-two-javascript-stream.md#2025-04-09_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` Connecting... Start consuming... First message received Marker found Done consuming, first offset was 0, last offset was 99 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Connecting to RabbitMQ using multiple endpoints in C# DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to connect to RabbitMQ using a list of endpoints, allowing for connection to alternate nodes in case of failure. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/client-libraries/dotnet-api-guide.md#2025-04-09_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: C# CODE: ``` ConnectionFactory factory = new ConnectionFactory(); factory.UserName = "username"; factory.Password = "s3Kre7"; var endpoints = new System.Collections.Generic.List { new AmqpTcpEndpoint("hostname"), new AmqpTcpEndpoint("localhost") }; IConnection conn = await factory.CreateConnectionAsync(endpoints); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring TLS Peer Verification in RabbitMQ with ini Format DESCRIPTION: Server configuration example showing how to enable TLS with peer verification, requiring client certificates. This configuration listens on port 5671 and specifies paths to CA certificate, server certificate, and server key. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/ssl/index.md#2025-04-09_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: ini CODE: ``` listeners.ssl.default = 5671 ssl_options.cacertfile = /path/to/ca_certificate.pem ssl_options.certfile = /path/to/server_certificate.pem ssl_options.keyfile = /path/to/server_key.pem ssl_options.verify = verify_peer ssl_options.fail_if_no_peer_cert = true ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring Heartbeat Timeout in Java RabbitMQ Client DESCRIPTION: Example showing how to set the heartbeat timeout to 60 seconds using the ConnectionFactory in Java client before creating a connection. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/heartbeats.md#2025-04-09_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: java CODE: ``` ConnectionFactory cf = new ConnectionFactory(); // set the heartbeat timeout to 60 seconds cf.setRequestedHeartbeat(60); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting Queue TTL via RabbitMQ Policy (Windows PowerShell) DESCRIPTION: Command to set a policy that makes all queues expire after 30 minutes (1,800,000 milliseconds) of inactivity using rabbitmqctl in Windows environment. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/ttl.md#2025-04-09_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: powershell CODE: ``` rabbitmqctl.bat set_policy expiry ".*" "{""expires"":1800000}" --apply-to queues ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Advanced Multi-Backend Authentication in RabbitMQ DESCRIPTION: Complex configuration for checking LDAP first and then falling back to the internal database. Users in LDAP must exist in the internal database for authorization but don't need a password there. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/access-control.md#2025-04-09_snippet_22 LANGUAGE: ini CODE: ``` # rabbitmq.conf # auth_backends.1.authn = ldap auth_backends.1.authz = internal auth_backends.2 = internal ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring AWS Peer Discovery for RabbitMQ Cluster Formation DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to configure RabbitMQ to use AWS for peer discovery, including setting the region, access keys, and other AWS-specific options. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/cluster-formation.md#2025-04-09_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: ini CODE: ``` cluster_formation.aws.region = us-east-1 cluster_formation.aws.access_key_id = ANIDEXAMPLE cluster_formation.aws.secret_key = WjalrxuTnFEMI/K7MDENG+bPxRfiCYEXAMPLEKEY ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Starting PerfTest Consumer with OAuth Client DESCRIPTION: This command starts a PerfTest consumer application authenticated using the OAuth client 'consumer_with_roles', which has read permissions mapped from custom scopes. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/oauth2-examples/index.md#2025-04-09_snippet_28 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` make start-perftest-consumer CONSUMER=consumer_with_roles ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Clearing Global Parameter in RabbitMQ DESCRIPTION: Command to clear a global runtime parameter named 'mqtt_default_vhosts'. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/man/rabbitmqctl.8.md#2025-04-09_snippet_46 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmqctl clear_global_parameter mqtt_default_vhosts ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting Up Python Environment for Pika OAuth Testing DESCRIPTION: Commands to set up a Python environment and install the required packages for testing OAuth authentication with the Pika AMQP client library. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/oauth2-examples-keycloak.md#2025-04-09_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` python3 --version pip install pika pip install requests python3 pika-client/producer.py producer kbOFBXI9tANgKUq8vXHLhT6YhbivgXxn ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: RabbitMQ Cluster Node Restart and Status Verification DESCRIPTION: Commands to restart RabbitMQ nodes and verify their cluster status after restart. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/clustering.md#2025-04-09_snippet_17 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` # on rabbit1 rabbitmq-server -detached rabbitmqctl cluster_status # => Cluster status of node rabbit@rabbit1 ... # => [{nodes,[{disc,[rabbit@rabbit1,rabbit@rabbit2,rabbit@rabbit3]}]}, # => {running_nodes,[rabbit@rabbit2,rabbit@rabbit1]}] # => ...done. # on rabbit2 rabbitmqctl cluster_status # => Cluster status of node rabbit@rabbit2 ... # => [{nodes,[{disc,[rabbit@rabbit1,rabbit@rabbit2,rabbit@rabbit3]}]}, # => {running_nodes,[rabbit@rabbit1,rabbit@rabbit2]}] # => ...done. # on rabbit3 rabbitmq-server -detached # on rabbit1 rabbitmqctl cluster_status # => Cluster status of node rabbit@rabbit1 ... # => [{nodes,[{disc,[rabbit@rabbit1,rabbit@rabbit2,rabbit@rabbit3]}]}, # => {running_nodes,[rabbit@rabbit2,rabbit@rabbit1,rabbit@rabbit3]}] # => ...done. # on rabbit2 rabbitmqctl cluster_status # => Cluster status of node rabbit@rabbit2 ... # => [{nodes,[{disc,[rabbit@rabbit1,rabbit@rabbit2,rabbit@rabbit3]}]}, # => {running_nodes,[rabbit@rabbit1,rabbit@rabbit2,rabbit@rabbit3]}] # => ...done. # on rabbit3 rabbitmqctl cluster_status # => Cluster status of node rabbit@rabbit3 ... # => [{nodes,[{disc,[rabbit@rabbit1,rabbit@rabbit2,rabbit@rabbit3]}]}, # => {running_nodes,[rabbit@rabbit2,rabbit@rabbit1,rabbit@rabbit3]}] # => ...done. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting Log Level in RabbitMQ DESCRIPTION: The set_log_level command adjusts the logging level of the running RabbitMQ node. Supported levels include debug, info, warning, error, critical, and none. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/man/rabbitmqctl.8.md#2025-04-09_snippet_67 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmqctl set_log_level debug ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating an Environment for RabbitMQ Streams in Java DESCRIPTION: Java code to create an Environment instance, which is the entry point for the RabbitMQ Stream Java client. It handles stream management and the creation of publisher and consumer instances. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/blog/2021-07-19-rabbitmq-streams-first-application/index.md#2025-04-09_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: java CODE: ``` try (Environment environment = Environment.builder() .uri("rabbitmq-stream://localhost:5552").build()) { // ... } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Declaring a Direct Exchange in Elixir DESCRIPTION: Code to create a direct exchange named 'direct_logs'. Direct exchanges route messages to queues based on the message routing key matching exactly with the queue binding key. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/tutorials/tutorial-four-elixir.md#2025-04-09_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: elixir CODE: ``` AMQP.Exchange.declare(channel, "direct_logs", :direct) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Emitting a Critical Kernel Log with Topic Exchange in Bash DESCRIPTION: This command runs the emit_log_topic.js script to send a log message with the routing key 'kern.critical' and a specified message content. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/tutorials/tutorial-five-javascript.md#2025-04-09_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` ./emit_log_topic.js "kern.critical" "A critical kernel error" ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Declaring Queue with TTL Using Java Client DESCRIPTION: Creates a RabbitMQ queue with a 30-minute expiration time using x-arguments during queue declaration in Java. The queue will be automatically deleted after 30 minutes of inactivity. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/ttl.md#2025-04-09_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: java CODE: ``` Map args = new HashMap(); args.put("x-expires", 1800000); channel.queueDeclare("myqueue", false, false, false, args); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using the rabbitmq-upgrade command with options DESCRIPTION: The basic syntax for the rabbitmq-upgrade command, showing available options including node specification, quiet mode, silent mode, timeout settings, and long name support. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/man/rabbitmq-upgrade.8.md#2025-04-09_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmq-upgrade [-q] [-s] [-l] [-n node] [-t timeout] command [command_options] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Checking Local Alarms in RabbitMQ (Bash) DESCRIPTION: Health check that fails if there are alarms in effect on the target node. Used to monitor resource alarms. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/man/rabbitmq-diagnostics.8.md#2025-04-09_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmq-diagnostics check_local_alarms ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: LDAP Certificate Chain Verification Depth DESCRIPTION: Sets the certificate chain verification depth for LDAP TLS connections. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/ldap.md#2025-04-09_snippet_22 LANGUAGE: ini CODE: ``` auth_ldap.ssl_options.depth = 5 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Adding a Quorum Queue Member in RabbitMQ (Bash) DESCRIPTION: Adds a replica (member) to a specific quorum queue on a given node. Requires specifying the virtual host, queue name, and target node. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/man/rabbitmq-queues.8.md#2025-04-09_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmq-queues add_member --vhost "a-vhost" "a-queue" "rabbit@new-node" ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Erlang Packages on Debian DESCRIPTION: Installs specific versions of Erlang packages required for RabbitMQ 3.13.x on Debian. This ensures compatibility with the latest available Erlang series. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/install-debian.md#2025-04-09_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` supported_erlang_version="1:26.2.5.6-1" sudo apt-get install -y erlang-base=$supported_erlang_version \ erlang-asn1=$supported_erlang_version \ erlang-crypto=$supported_erlang_version \ erlang-eldap=$supported_erlang_version \ erlang-ftp=$supported_erlang_version \ erlang-inets=$supported_erlang_version \ erlang-mnesia=$supported_erlang_version \ erlang-os-mon=$supported_erlang_version \ erlang-parsetools=$supported_erlang_version \ erlang-public-key=$supported_erlang_version \ erlang-runtime-tools=$supported_erlang_version \ erlang-snmp=$supported_erlang_version \ erlang-ssl=$supported_erlang_version \ erlang-syntax-tools=$supported_erlang_version \ erlang-tftp=$supported_erlang_version \ erlang-tools=$supported_erlang_version \ erlang-xmerl=$supported_erlang_version ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Complex Messages with RabbitMQ Stream in Java DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to create a message with custom properties in RabbitMQ Streams using the Java client. It sets creation time and message ID properties before adding the message body data. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/blog/2021-10-07-rabbitmq-streams-interoperability/index.md#2025-04-09_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: java CODE: ``` Message message = producer.messageBuilder() .properties() .creationTime(System.currentTimeMillis()) // Unix time, with a precision of milliseconds .messageId(i) // long, string, binary, or UUID .messageBuilder() .addData("hello world".getBytes(StandardCharsets.UTF_8)) .build(); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Listing Cipher Suites in Erlang Format with RabbitMQ Diagnostics DESCRIPTION: This command lists cipher suites in Erlang format, which is only accepted in the classic config format of RabbitMQ. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/ssl/index.md#2025-04-09_snippet_32 LANGUAGE: ini CODE: ``` rabbitmq-diagnostics cipher_suites --format erlang -q ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring Heartbeat Timeout in Java RabbitMQ Client DESCRIPTION: Example showing how to set the heartbeat timeout to 60 seconds using the ConnectionFactory in Java client before creating a connection. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/heartbeats.md#2025-04-09_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: java CODE: ``` ConnectionFactory cf = new ConnectionFactory(); // set the heartbeat timeout to 60 seconds cf.setRequestedHeartbeat(60); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Complete Log Receiver with Direct Exchange in Swift RabbitMQ Client DESCRIPTION: Full implementation of a function that receives log messages of various severities. It binds a queue to a direct exchange with multiple routing keys and subscribes to messages. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/tutorials/tutorial-four-swift.md#2025-04-09_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: swift CODE: ``` func receiveLogsDirect() { let conn = RMQConnection(delegate: RMQConnectionDelegateLogger()) conn.start() let ch = conn.createChannel() let x = ch.direct("direct_logs") let q = ch.queue("", options: .exclusive) let severities = ["error", "warning", "info"] for severity: String in severities { q.bind(x, routingKey: severity) } print("Waiting for logs.") q.subscribe({(_ message: RMQMessage) -> Void in print("\(message.routingKey):\(String(data: message.body, encoding: .utf8))") }) } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating User and Permissions for MQTT Connections in RabbitMQ DESCRIPTION: Command sequence for setting up a new user with appropriate permissions for MQTT connections. These commands create a user with full access to the default virtual host and assign management tags for UI access. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/docs/mqtt.md#2025-04-09_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` # username and password are both "mqtt-test" rabbitmqctl add_user mqtt-test mqtt-test rabbitmqctl set_permissions -p "/" mqtt-test ".*" ".*" ".*" rabbitmqctl set_user_tags mqtt-test management ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing RabbitMQ Delayed Message Exchange Plugin DESCRIPTION: Command to enable the rabbitmq_delayed_message_exchange plugin after downloading and copying it to RabbitMQ's plugin folder. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/blog/2015-04-16-scheduling-messages-with-rabbitmq/index.md#2025-04-09_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` rabbitmq-plugins enable rabbitmq_delayed_message_exchange ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: MQTT Retained Message Store Configuration DESCRIPTION: Complete configuration example for MQTT plugin including retained message store settings, anonymous access, vhost configuration, and listener ports. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/docs/mqtt.md#2025-04-09_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: ini CODE: ``` mqtt.allow_anonymous = true mqtt.vhost = / mqtt.exchange = amq.topic mqtt.max_session_expiry_interval_seconds = 1800 mqtt.prefetch = 10 ## use DETS (disk-based) store for retained messages mqtt.retained_message_store = rabbit_mqtt_retained_msg_store_dets ## only used by DETS store mqtt.retained_message_store_dets_sync_interval = 2000 mqtt.listeners.ssl = none mqtt.listeners.tcp.default = 1883 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Binding a Queue to an Exchange in Ruby DESCRIPTION: Establishes a binding between a queue and the 'logs' exchange. This relationship determines how messages flow from the exchange to the queue. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/tutorials/tutorial-three-ruby.md#2025-04-09_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: ruby CODE: ``` queue.bind('logs') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring Consul Endpoint for RabbitMQ Peer Discovery DESCRIPTION: Specifies Consul host, port, and URI scheme for RabbitMQ peer discovery. This enables RabbitMQ nodes to communicate with Consul for service discovery. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/cluster-formation.md#2025-04-09_snippet_20 LANGUAGE: ini CODE: ``` cluster_formation.peer_discovery_backend = consul cluster_formation.consul.host = consul.eng.example.local # 8500 is used by default cluster_formation.consul.port = 8500 # http is used by default cluster_formation.consul.scheme = http ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting HTTP Proxy for RabbitMQ Peer Discovery DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to configure HTTP and HTTPS proxy servers for RabbitMQ peer discovery mechanisms that use HTTP. It sets the cluster_formation.proxy.http_proxy and cluster_formation.proxy.https_proxy options. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/docs/cluster-formation.md#2025-04-09_snippet_49 LANGUAGE: ini CODE: ``` cluster_formation.proxy.http_proxy = 192.168.0.98 cluster_formation.proxy.https_proxy = 192.168.0.98 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: RabbitMQ Version Upgrade Compatibility Table DESCRIPTION: Markdown table showing compatibility between RabbitMQ versions for rolling upgrades, including specific version requirements and feature flag considerations. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/upgrade.md#2025-04-09_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` | From | To | Notes | |----------|--------|-------------------------------------------------------------| | 3.12.x | 3.13.x | | | 3.11.18 | 3.12.x | All feature flags **must** be enabled **before** the upgrade | | 3.10.x | 3.11.x | Some feature flags **must** be enabled **before** the upgrade | | 3.9.x | 3.10.x | | | 3.8.x | 3.9.x | | | 3.7.18 | 3.8.x | | ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Importing Definitions using rabbitmqctl DESCRIPTION: Command to import RabbitMQ definitions using rabbitmqctl, which doesn't require the management plugin to be enabled. This applies schema metadata from the specified JSON file. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/definitions.md#2025-04-09_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: ini CODE: ``` # Does not require management plugin to be enabled rabbitmqctl import_definitions /path/to/definitions.file.json ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Declaring Queue with Maximum Length in Java DESCRIPTION: This Java code snippet declares a queue with a maximum length of 10 messages using the x-max-length argument. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/maxlength/index.md#2025-04-09_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: java CODE: ``` Map args = new HashMap(); args.put("x-max-length", 10); channel.queueDeclare("myqueue", false, false, false, args); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Enabling the RabbitMQ Prometheus Plugin DESCRIPTION: Command to enable the rabbitmq_prometheus plugin which exposes RabbitMQ metrics in Prometheus format for monitoring. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/monitoring/index.md#2025-04-09_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmq-plugins enable rabbitmq_prometheus ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Listing Supported Cipher Suites in RabbitMQ with Bash DESCRIPTION: Lists all cipher suites supported by encoding commands in RabbitMQ. This command helps identify available encryption options for secure communications. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/man/rabbitmqctl.8.md#2025-04-09_snippet_36 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmqctl list_ciphers ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring systemd Limits for RabbitMQ on Linux DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to set the maximum open file handle limit (nofile) to 64000 for RabbitMQ using systemd on modern Linux distributions. The configuration is done in a file located at /etc/systemd/system/rabbitmq-server.service.d/limits.conf. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/configure.md#2025-04-09_snippet_53 LANGUAGE: ini CODE: ``` [Service] LimitNOFILE=64000 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Complete Log Receiver Implementation DESCRIPTION: Full implementation of a consumer that receives and processes log messages from the fanout exchange. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/tutorials/tutorial-three-python.md#2025-04-09_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` #!/usr/bin/env python import pika connection = pika.BlockingConnection( pika.ConnectionParameters(host='localhost')) channel = connection.channel() channel.exchange_declare(exchange='logs', exchange_type='fanout') result = channel.queue_declare(queue='', exclusive=True) queue_name = result.method.queue channel.queue_bind(exchange='logs', queue=queue_name) print(' [*] Waiting for logs. To exit press CTRL+C') def callback(ch, method, properties, body): print(f" [x] {body}") channel.basic_consume( queue=queue_name, on_message_callback=callback, auto_ack=True) channel.start_consuming() ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring Alternate Exchange Using Policy in Bash DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to set a policy for an Alternate Exchange using the rabbitmqctl command in Bash. It applies an AE named 'my-ae' to an exchange called 'my-direct'. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/ae.md#2025-04-09_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmqctl set_policy AE "^my-direct$" '{"alternate-exchange":"my-ae"}' --apply-to exchanges ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Managing Stream Replicas in RabbitMQ using CLI DESCRIPTION: Commands for adding and removing stream replicas using the rabbitmq-streams CLI tool. Includes options for specifying virtual hosts and stream names. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/streams.md#2025-04-09_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmq-streams add_replica [-p ] ``` LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmq-streams delete_replica [-p ] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Channel in RabbitMQ with JavaScript DESCRIPTION: Creates a channel after connecting to RabbitMQ, which is necessary for performing operations like declaring queues and sending messages. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/tutorials/tutorial-one-javascript.md#2025-04-09_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: javascript CODE: ``` amqp.connect('amqp://localhost', function(error0, connection) { if (error0) { throw error0; } connection.createChannel(function(error1, channel) {}); }); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Publishing Messages to RabbitMQ Stream in Rust DESCRIPTION: Publishes a series of messages to a stream with a marker message at the end, using async confirmation callbacks to ensure delivery. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/tutorials/tutorial-two-rust-stream.md#2025-04-09_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: rust CODE: ``` let producer = environment.producer().build(stream).await?; println!("Publishing {:?} messages", message_count); for i in 0..message_count { let msg; if i < message_count - 1 { msg = Message::builder().body(format!("hello{}", i)).build(); } else { msg = Message::builder().body(format!("marker{}", i)).build(); }; let counter = confirmed_messages.clone(); let notifier = notify_on_send.clone(); producer .send(msg, move |_| { let inner_counter = counter.clone(); let inner_notifier = notifier.clone(); async move { if inner_counter.fetch_add(1, Ordering::Relaxed) == message_count - 1 { inner_notifier.notify_one(); } } }) .await?; } notify_on_send.notified().await; println!("Messages confirmed: True"); producer.close().await? ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Implementing Offset Tracking in RabbitMQ Stream Consumer DESCRIPTION: Python implementation of a RabbitMQ Stream consumer with offset tracking functionality. The code handles message processing, stores offsets every 10 messages, and implements recovery logic to resume from the last stored position. Key features include named consumers, periodic offset storage, and offset querying on startup. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/tutorials/tutorial-two-python-stream.md#2025-04-09_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: python CODE: ``` async def on_message(msg: AMQPMessage, message_context: MessageContext): # variable to keep track of the number of received messages global message_count global first_offset global last_offset offset = message_context.offset if first_offset == -1: print("First message received") first_offset = offset consumer = message_context.consumer stream = message_context.consumer.get_stream(message_context.subscriber_name) # store the offset after every 10 messages received message_count = message_count + 1 if message_count % 10 == 0: # store_message needs to take a subscriber_name parameter await consumer.store_offset( stream=stream, offset=offset, subscriber_name=message_context.subscriber_name, ) # store the offset after receiving the marker message if "marker" in str(msg): await consumer.store_offset( stream=stream, offset=offset, subscriber_name=message_context.subscriber_name, ) last_offset = offset await consumer.close() async def consume(): # the offset to start consuming from stored_offset = -1 global first_offset global last_offset # start a consumer and creates the stream is not exist (same as before...) try: await consumer.start() print("Started consuming: Press control +C to close") try: # query_offset must take a subscriber_name as parameter stored_offset = await consumer.query_offset( stream=STREAM_NAME, subscriber_name="subscriber_1" ) except OffsetNotFound as offset_exception: print(f"Offset not previously stored. {offset_exception}") except ServerError as server_error: print(f"Server error: {server_error}") exit(1) # if no offset was previously stored start from the first offset stored_offset = stored_offset + 1 await consumer.subscribe( stream=STREAM_NAME, # We explicitely need to assign a name to the consumer subscriber_name="subscriber_1", callback=on_message, decoder=amqp_decoder, offset_specification=ConsumerOffsetSpecification( OffsetType.OFFSET, stored_offset ), ) await consumer.run() except (KeyboardInterrupt, asyncio.exceptions.CancelledError): await consumer.close() ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Viewing PerfTest Producer Logs DESCRIPTION: Command to view the logs of the running producer application to debug OAuth 2.0 authentication. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/oauth2-examples/index.md#2025-04-09_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` docker logs producer -f ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Deleting a Queue Only if Unused in RabbitMQ Java Client DESCRIPTION: Deletes a queue only if it has no consumers. The operation will fail if the queue has active consumers, leaving it intact. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/client-libraries/java-api-guide.md#2025-04-09_snippet_13 LANGUAGE: java CODE: ``` channel.queueDelete("queue-name", true, false) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Running RabbitMQ Server in Background Mode DESCRIPTION: This command starts the RabbitMQ AMQP server in detached (background) mode. When run with the -detached flag, the server process runs in the background and does not write to the PID file. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/docs/man/rabbitmq-server.8.md#2025-04-09_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmq-server -detached ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Verifying Erlang Cookie Configuration in RabbitMQ DESCRIPTION: Command that displays comprehensive information about the Erlang cookie configuration used by RabbitMQ CLI tools, including the effective user, home directory, cookie file path and access permissions. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/clustering.md#2025-04-09_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmq-diagnostics erlang_cookie_sources ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Complete Worker Implementation in RabbitMQ with JavaScript DESCRIPTION: Full implementation of a worker (worker.js) that consumes and processes messages from a RabbitMQ queue with durability, manual acknowledgment and fair dispatch. The worker connects to RabbitMQ, sets up a channel with prefetch limit, and processes messages with simulated work time before acknowledging them. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/tutorials/tutorial-two-javascript.md#2025-04-09_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: javascript CODE: ``` #!/usr/bin/env node var amqp = require('amqplib/callback_api'); amqp.connect('amqp://localhost', function(error0, connection) { if (error0) { throw error0; } connection.createChannel(function(error1, channel) { if (error1) { throw error1; } var queue = 'task_queue'; channel.assertQueue(queue, { durable: true }); channel.prefetch(1); console.log(" [*] Waiting for messages in %s. To exit press CTRL+C", queue); channel.consume(queue, function(msg) { var secs = msg.content.toString().split('.').length - 1; console.log(" [x] Received %s", msg.content.toString()); setTimeout(function() { console.log(" [x] Done"); channel.ack(msg); }, secs * 1000); }, { // manual acknowledgment mode, // see /docs/confirms for details noAck: false }); }); }); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Running RabbitMQ with Docker Management Plugin DESCRIPTION: Example Docker command to run the latest RabbitMQ 3.13 with the management plugin enabled, exposing ports 5672 (AMQP) and 15672 (management interface). SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/download.md#2025-04-09_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` # latest RabbitMQ 3.13 docker run -it --rm --name rabbitmq -p 5672:5672 -p 15672:15672 rabbitmq:3.13-management ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Granting Permissions to Users in RabbitMQ DESCRIPTION: Shows how to grant permissions to a user in a specific virtual host using the rabbitmqctl command. Examples are provided for both Bash and PowerShell, demonstrating how to set configure, write, and read permissions. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/docs/access-control.md#2025-04-09_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` # First ".*" for configure permission on every entity # Second ".*" for write permission on every entity # Third ".*" for read permission on every entity rabbitmqctl set_permissions -p "custom-vhost" "username" ".*" ".*" ".*" ``` LANGUAGE: powershell CODE: ``` # First ".*" for configure permission on every entity # Second ".*" for write permission on every entity # Third ".*" for read permission on every entity rabbitmqctl.bat set_permissions -p 'custom-vhost' 'username' '.*' '.*' '.*' ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Complete Producer Implementation for RabbitMQ Work Queue in Objective-C DESCRIPTION: Complete implementation of a task producer for RabbitMQ work queues in Objective-C. It establishes a connection, creates a durable queue, and publishes persistent messages to the queue. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/tutorials/tutorial-two-objectivec.md#2025-04-09_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: objectivec CODE: ``` - (void)newTask:(NSString *)msg { RMQConnection *conn = [[RMQConnection alloc] initWithDelegate:[RMQConnectionDelegateLogger new]]; [conn start]; id ch = [conn createChannel]; RMQQueue *q = [ch queue:@"task_queue" options:RMQQueueDeclareDurable]; NSData *msgData = [msg dataUsingEncoding:NSUTF8StringEncoding]; [ch.defaultExchange publish:msgData routingKey:q.name persistent:YES]; NSLog(@"Sent %@", msg); [conn close]; } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring TLS for RabbitMQ etcd Discovery DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to configure TLS for secure connections between RabbitMQ and etcd in the peer discovery process. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/docs/cluster-formation.md#2025-04-09_snippet_43 LANGUAGE: ini CODE: ``` cluster_formation.peer_discovery_backend = etcd cluster_formation.etcd.endpoints.1 = one.etcd.eng.example.local:2379 cluster_formation.etcd.endpoints.2 = two.etcd.eng.example.local:2479 # trusted CA certificate file path cluster_formation.etcd.ssl_options.cacertfile = /path/to/ca_certificate.pem # client certificate (public key) file path cluster_formation.etcd.ssl_options.certfile = /path/to/client_certificate.pem # client private key file path cluster_formation.etcd.ssl_options.keyfile = /path/to/client_key.pem # use TLSv1.2 for connections cluster_formation.etcd.ssl_options.versions.1 = tlsv1.2 # enables peer verification (the plugin will verify the certificate chain of the server) cluster_formation.etcd.ssl_options.verify = verify_peer cluster_formation.etcd.ssl_options.fail_if_no_peer_cert = true ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Complete RabbitMQ TLS Connection Example in .NET DESCRIPTION: Full example demonstrating how to establish a TLS connection to RabbitMQ, create a channel, and perform basic queue operations using the .NET client with async/await pattern. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/docs/ssl/index.md#2025-04-09_snippet_25 LANGUAGE: csharp CODE: ``` using System; using System.IO; using System.Text; using RabbitMQ.client; namespace RabbitMQ.client.Examples { public class TestSSL { public static async Task Main(string[] args) { ConnectionFactory cf = new ConnectionFactory(); cf.Ssl.Enabled = true; cf.Ssl.ServerName = System.Net.Dns.GetHostName(); cf.Ssl.CertPath = "/path/to/client_key.p12"; cf.Ssl.CertPassphrase = "MySecretPassword"; using (IConnection conn = await cf.CreateConnectionAsync()) { using (IChannel ch = await conn.CreateChannelAsync()) { Console.WriteLine("Successfully connected and opened a channel"); await ch.QueueDeclareAsync("rabbitmq-dotnet-test", false, false, false, null); Console.WriteLine("Successfully declared a queue"); await ch.QueueDeleteAsync("rabbitmq-dotnet-test"); Console.WriteLine("Successfully deleted the queue"); } } return 0; } } } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Consuming RabbitMQ Stream Messages with Specific Offset DESCRIPTION: Shows how to consume messages from a specific offset position in a RabbitMQ stream using a numerical offset value. Includes required QoS configuration and acknowledgment handling. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/streams.md#2025-04-09_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: java CODE: ``` channel.basicQos(100); // QoS must be specified channel.basicConsume( "my-stream", false, Collections.singletonMap("x-stream-offset", 5000), // offset value (consumerTag, message) -> { // message processing // ... channel.basicAck(message.getEnvelope().getDeliveryTag(), false); // ack is required }, consumerTag -> { }); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Rebalancing Subset of Quorum Queues by Name in RabbitMQ DESCRIPTION: CLI command to rebalance a subset of quorum queues selected by name pattern. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/quorum-queues/index.md#2025-04-09_snippet_16 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmq-queues rebalance quorum --queue-pattern "orders.*" ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring RabbitMQ TLS Support in Erlang Format DESCRIPTION: Example configuration in classic Erlang term format for enabling TLS in RabbitMQ, specifying the TLS listener port, certificate files, and peer verification settings. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/docs/ssl/index.md#2025-04-09_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: erlang CODE: ``` [ {rabbit, [ {ssl_listeners, [5671]}, {ssl_options, [{cacertfile, "/path/to/ca_certificate.pem"}, {certfile, "/path/to/server_certificate.pem"}, {keyfile, "/path/to/server_key.pem"}, {verify, verify_peer}, {fail_if_no_peer_cert, true}]} ]} ]. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: RabbitMQ Log Level Configuration DESCRIPTION: Logging granularity configuration SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/configure.md#2025-04-09_snippet_23 LANGUAGE: ini CODE: ``` log.file.level = info ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: RabbitMQ Log Level Configuration DESCRIPTION: Logging granularity configuration SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/configure.md#2025-04-09_snippet_23 LANGUAGE: ini CODE: ``` log.file.level = info ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Deleting a Stream Replica using RabbitMQ CLI DESCRIPTION: This command removes a replica from a specified stream on a given node. It requires the virtual host, stream name, and target node as parameters. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/streams.md#2025-04-09_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmq-streams delete_replica [-p ] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Subscribing to a RabbitMQ Queue for Message Consumption DESCRIPTION: Subscribes to the 'hello' queue to asynchronously receive messages pushed by the RabbitMQ server. When a message is received, it prints the message body content to the console. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/tutorials/tutorial-one-swift.md#2025-04-09_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: Swift CODE: ``` print("Waiting for messages.") q.subscribe({(_ message: RMQMessage) -> Void in print("Received \(String(data: message.body, encoding: .utf8))") }) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring TCP Acceptors in RabbitMQ (INI) DESCRIPTION: Default setting for the number of Erlang processes that will accept connections for TCP listeners. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/docs/configure.md#2025-04-09_snippet_17 LANGUAGE: ini CODE: ``` num_acceptors.tcp = 10 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Publishing Messages with RabbitMQ in Go DESCRIPTION: Shows how to create a publisher and publish messages to an exchange with a routing key or directly to a queue using the RabbitMQ Go client library. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/client-libraries/amqp-client-libraries.md#2025-04-09_snippet_25 LANGUAGE: Go CODE: ``` // // no target defined on publisher creation (nil) publisher, err := connection.NewPublisher(context.Background(), nil, nil) // create message with an exchange with a routing key msg, err = NewMessageWithAddress([]byte("hello"), &ExchangeAddress{ Exchange: "foo", Key: "bar", }) // create a message with a queue msg, err = NewMessageWithAddress([]byte("hello"), &QueueAddress{ Queue: "some-queue"}) // use the publish publishResult, err = publisher.Publish(context.Background(), msg) // ... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Adding Erlang Repository for Ubuntu 22.04 (Jammy) DESCRIPTION: Adds the Launchpad PPA repository for Erlang packages produced by the RabbitMQ team to /etc/apt/sources.list.d/erlang.list for Ubuntu 22.04 (Jammy). This repository is specifically for amd64 architecture and uses GPG key verification. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/install-debian.md#2025-04-09_snippet_25 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` # This Launchpad PPA repository provides Erlang packages produced by the RabbitMQ team # # Replace $distribution with the name of the Ubuntu release used deb [arch=amd64 signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/net.launchpad.ppa.rabbitmq.erlang.gpg] http://ppa.launchpad.net/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-erlang/ubuntu jammy main deb-src [signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/net.launchpad.ppa.rabbitmq.erlang.gpg] http://ppa.launchpad.net/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-erlang/ubuntu jammy main ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Java Publisher Confirms Code Example DESCRIPTION: Interface references for implementing publisher confirms in RabbitMQ Java client. Shows how to handle confirmation callbacks for published messages using ConfirmCallback and ConfirmListener interfaces. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/publishers/index.md#2025-04-09_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: java CODE: ``` // Add confirm listeners to a channel channel.addConfirmListener(confirmCallback, confirmCallback); // Interfaces used: // ConfirmCallback // ConfirmListener ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting Up Consumer for Receiving Messages in Ruby DESCRIPTION: Initializes a consumer that listens for messages from a specified queue. This snippet is part of the consumer (receiver) script. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/tutorials/tutorial-one-ruby.md#2025-04-09_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: ruby CODE: ``` connection = Bunny.new connection.start channel = connection.create_channel queue = channel.queue('hello') begin puts ' [*] Waiting for messages. To exit press CTRL+C' queue.subscribe(block: true) do |_delivery_info, _properties, body| puts " [x] Received #{body}" end rescue Interrupt => _ connection.close exit(0) end ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring TCP Listener Options for MQTT in RabbitMQ DESCRIPTION: Sets various TCP listener options including buffer sizes, connection queue length, TCP keepalives, and timeouts. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/mqtt.md#2025-04-09_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: ini CODE: ``` mqtt.listeners.tcp.1 = 127.0.0.1:1883 mqtt.listeners.tcp.2 = ::1:1883 mqtt.tcp_listen_options.backlog = 4096 mqtt.tcp_listen_options.buffer = 131072 mqtt.tcp_listen_options.recbuf = 131072 mqtt.tcp_listen_options.sndbuf = 131072 mqtt.tcp_listen_options.keepalive = true mqtt.tcp_listen_options.nodelay = true mqtt.tcp_listen_options.exit_on_close = true mqtt.tcp_listen_options.send_timeout = 120 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Checking RabbitMQ Cluster Status DESCRIPTION: Commands to verify cluster status across all three nodes, showing both disc nodes and running nodes in the cluster. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/clustering.md#2025-04-09_snippet_13 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` # on rabbit1 rabbitmqctl cluster_status # => Cluster status of node rabbit@rabbit1 ... # => [{nodes,[{disc,[rabbit@rabbit1,rabbit@rabbit2,rabbit@rabbit3]}]}, # => {running_nodes,[rabbit@rabbit3,rabbit@rabbit2,rabbit@rabbit1]}] # => ...done. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring TLS Peer Verification in RabbitMQ with Erlang Format DESCRIPTION: Classic configuration format (Erlang) for enabling TLS with peer verification in RabbitMQ. Sets up SSL listeners on port 5671 and configures certificate paths along with verification settings. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/ssl/index.md#2025-04-09_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: erlang CODE: ``` [ {rabbit, [ {ssl_listeners, [5671]}, {ssl_options, [{cacertfile,"/path/to/ca_certificate.pem"}, {certfile,"/path/to/server_certificate.pem"}, {keyfile,"/path/to/server_key.pem"}, {verify, verify_peer}, {fail_if_no_peer_cert, true}]} ]} ]. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring Advanced Multi-Backend Authentication in RabbitMQ DESCRIPTION: This advanced configuration checks LDAP first for authentication, uses internal database for authorization, and falls back to internal database for both if the user is not found in LDAP. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/docs/access-control.md#2025-04-09_snippet_20 LANGUAGE: ini CODE: ``` # rabbitmq.conf # auth_backends.1.authn = ldap auth_backends.1.authz = internal auth_backends.2 = internal ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Pinging a RabbitMQ Node DESCRIPTION: Checks if a specific RabbitMQ node is up, registered with EPMD, and accessible for CLI tool authentication. The command uses the 'ping' action and specifies the target node using the '-n' flag. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/docs/man/rabbitmqctl.8.md#2025-04-09_snippet_42 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmqctl ping -n rabbit@hostname ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Running RabbitMQ Stream Publisher in Java DESCRIPTION: Command to compile and run the Send class which publishes messages to a RabbitMQ stream. This can be run multiple times to send additional messages. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/tutorials/tutorial-one-java-stream.md#2025-04-09_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` ./mvnw -q compile exec:java '-Dexec.mainClass=Send' ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Complete Log Publisher Implementation with RabbitMQ in Java DESCRIPTION: A full implementation of a log message publisher that connects to RabbitMQ, declares a fanout exchange named 'logs', and publishes messages to it. Messages are broadcast to all consumers listening on queues bound to this exchange. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/tutorials/tutorial-three-java.md#2025-04-09_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: java CODE: ``` public class EmitLog { private static final String EXCHANGE_NAME = "logs"; public static void main(String[] argv) throws Exception { ConnectionFactory factory = new ConnectionFactory(); factory.setHost("localhost"); try (Connection connection = factory.newConnection(); Channel channel = connection.createChannel()) { channel.exchangeDeclare(EXCHANGE_NAME, "fanout"); String message = argv.length < 1 ? "info: Hello World!" : String.join(" ", argv); channel.basicPublish(EXCHANGE_NAME, "", null, message.getBytes("UTF-8")); System.out.println(" [x] Sent '" + message + "'"); } } } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Visualizing RabbitMQ Basic Message Flow using Mermaid DESCRIPTION: This diagram illustrates the fundamental messaging pattern in RabbitMQ with a producer sending messages to a queue named 'hello', which are then consumed by a consumer. The diagram uses Mermaid's flowchart syntax with custom styling for the producer, queue, and consumer elements. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/src/components/Tutorials/T1DiagramHello.md#2025-04-09_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: mermaid CODE: ``` flowchart LR P((P)) Q[[hello]] C((C)) P --> Q --> C class P mermaid-producer class Q mermaid-queue class C mermaid-consumer ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Positive Message Acknowledgement in .NET DESCRIPTION: Shows positive message acknowledgement implementation using RabbitMQ .NET client. Uses IModel#BasicAck with EventingBasicConsumer to handle individual message acknowledgement. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/docs/confirms.md#2025-04-09_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: csharp CODE: ``` var consumer = new EventingBasicConsumer(channel); consumer.Received += (ch, ea) => { var body = ea.Body.ToArray(); // positively acknowledge a single delivery, the message will // be discarded channel.BasicAck(ea.DeliveryTag, false); }; String consumerTag = channel.BasicConsume(queueName, false, consumer); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring Dropwizard Metrics with JMX for RabbitMQ Java Client DESCRIPTION: Shows how to set up Dropwizard Metrics with JMX reporting for the RabbitMQ Java client. It demonstrates creating a MetricRegistry, passing it to the StandardMetricsCollector, setting the collector on the ConnectionFactory, and configuring a JMX reporter. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/client-libraries/java-api-guide.md#2025-04-09_snippet_43 LANGUAGE: java CODE: ``` MetricRegistry registry = new MetricRegistry(); StandardMetricsCollector metrics = new StandardMetricsCollector(registry); ConnectionFactory connectionFactory = new ConnectionFactory(); connectionFactory.setMetricsCollector(metrics); JmxReporter reporter = JmxReporter .forRegistry(registry) .inDomain("com.rabbitmq.client.jmx") .build(); reporter.start(); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Implementing Fibonacci Function in PHP DESCRIPTION: A recursive implementation of the Fibonacci sequence in PHP. This function is used as the core computation for the RPC example. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/tutorials/tutorial-six-php.md#2025-04-09_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: php CODE: ``` function fib($n) { if ($n == 0) { return 0; } if ($n == 1) { return 1; } return fib($n-1) + fib($n-2); } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring OAuth 2.0 Issuer in RabbitMQ (Erlang) DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to configure the OAuth 2.0 issuer URL in RabbitMQ using the Erlang format. It sets the resource server ID and the issuer URL. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/oauth2.md#2025-04-09_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: erlang CODE: ``` [ {rabbitmq_auth_backend_oauth2, [ {resource_server_id, <<"my_rabbit_server">>}, {issuer, <<"https://my-idp-provider/somerealm">>} ]}, ]. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Monitoring-Only User in RabbitMQ (Windows CMD) DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to create a user with monitoring-only access to the RabbitMQ management UI using Windows CMD commands. It includes steps to add a user with different password examples and grant empty permissions. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/management/index.md#2025-04-09_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: batch CODE: ``` rem See the Access Control guide to learn about user management. rem password is provided as a command line argument rabbitmqctl.bat add_user "monitoring" "9a55f70a841f18b97c3a7db939b7adc9e34a0f1d" rem passwords with special characters must be quoted correctly rabbitmqctl.bat add_user "monitoring" "w63pnZ&LnYMO(t" rem grant the user empty permissions rabbitmqctl set_permissions --vhost "vhost-name" "monitoring" "^$" "^$" "^$" ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Virtual Host Using RabbitMQ CLI DESCRIPTION: Creates a new virtual host named 'qa1' using the rabbitmqctl command line tool. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-4.0/vhosts.md#2025-04-09_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` rabbitmqctl add_vhost qa1 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Basic RabbitMQ Upgrade Command Usage DESCRIPTION: Basic command syntax for rabbitmq-upgrade showing the main command structure with optional flags for quiet mode, silent mode, long names, node specification, and timeout settings. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/man/rabbitmq-upgrade.8.md#2025-04-09_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` rabbitmq-upgrade [-q] [-s] [-l] [-n node] [-t timeout] command [command_options] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing RabbitMQ Server on Debian DESCRIPTION: Installs the RabbitMQ server package and its dependencies using apt. The --fix-missing flag is used to handle any potential missing dependencies. SOURCE: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-website/blob/main/versioned_docs/version-3.13/install-debian.md#2025-04-09_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` sudo apt-get install rabbitmq-server -y --fix-missing ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Java Client with TLS Peer Verification DESCRIPTION: Java example demonstrating a complete RabbitMQ client implementation with TLS peer verification. The code configures key stores, trust stores, TLS context, and establishes a secure connection to RabbitMQ.
